title: How to explain deafness or blindness to a child born that way - Quora

response.answer_text: This question is clearly ableist/audist and assumes that Deaf kids need to have things explained to them. (Laughs) I was born Deaf and I figured out I was Deaf all on my own. My hearing parents never needed to explain to me that I was Deaf. The earliest memory I can remember is knowing signed language would work for me. I was only 2 1/2 years old then. My next earliest memory was around age five or six when I realized that Deaf people and hearing people had different culture and many of their values conflicted with each other. Your details are also ableist because it assumes that one must be totally abled in order to have a “social development.” (It’s also audist because it assumes that one has to be hearing or act like a hearing person in order to have a ‘normal’ social development. FYI…there are all kinds of normal, and HEARING isn’t the only kind of normal or even the best kind of normal. With Deaf children, all that is needed is for their parents to SIGN and have signed conversations with them. Visually accessible language is critical…once Deaf children have that, then they are able to receive their education, develop cognitively, develop socially, and do everything they want to do. Withhold signed language from a Deaf child…you’re talking about language deprivation, problems with social development, communication issues, and so forth. As for blind children…they have different needs than Deaf children (why did you lump us together, OP?!). I’m not an expert on blindness so I will leave it to other blind Quorans to answer that part.

I’ve never had to do this, but I have a fun experience that I can share with you. My ASL teacher showed us this story about Deaf children. There once was a six year old boy who was born completely deaf, he and his mom lived together. His friends come over all of the time, even though they can’t communicate very well, they still have fun together. The little boy asks his mom if he can go over to his friends house to hang out with him, she says yes. He’s really excited and goes running over to his house and knocks on the other boys door. The boy opens it with his mother standing near by, all of the sudden, all the Deaf boy sees is the other boy and his moms lips moving, he runs home, astonished by his new discovery. “MOM, MOM, did you know that people communicate with their mouths?!!?? How do they do that, it seems really hard?” His mom then smiles and explains to him that people can communicate differently than they do, similar to how Hearing people explain that Deaf people communicate differently than we do. The Deaf child isn’t impacted negatively by the lack of English yet, he can function normally, and still has friends. The hard part comes when he starts growing up and faces discrimination because of his language. I think something similar occurs with blindness, but I’m not sure.

I got a request to answer this, but I am not blind, Deaf, or Deaf-blind, so I am not qualified to answer it from a personal perspective, and won’t try. I will note that I have several Deaf friends with Deaf children, and no one has ever mentioned “Oh, tonight we’re telling him he’d Deaf.” I don’t think it works like that. Children grow up realizing that people are not identical, that they may have blue eyes and blonde hair, and someone else may have brown eyes and red hair, and just accept it. I doubt that a Deaf child needs a “concept of Deafness” to develop a Deaf identity anymore than a little girl needs a “concept of female” to develop an identity as a girl, or an African-American child needs a “concept of race” to develop an identity as an African-American person. I can tell you that there is a book called Deaf Like Me, and the title comes from the ability of a pretty young child who was able (enabled, when her parents decided that oralism was not for them, and their daughter would learn ASL, as would they) to tell her parents that some adults she just met were “Deaf, like me.”

You can't explain to a child because he or she is too young to understand but expose her or him saying like this “ water moves but no sound”, “birds move with their beak but no sound”, “ look people are dancing and have him or her feel the music but no sound”, the child will understand eventually by pointing to what animals do, what people do, what everything does now. Then you tell her or him that they are fine for the way they are. Let them know that there is an awesome Deaf culture that they will grow up in and will have a lot of fun learning. There is no limit and let them look forward to growing up to be a wonderful Deaf person in the community. Expose the Deaf culture as much as possible and they will love it, guarantee it!
